It was not the policy intention to exclude interpreters and translators who have a pre-existing advanced level of proficiency in the English language. I agree that it is not appropriate to exclude such persons from the GSM program because they do not meet the `all instruction in English' requirement.

(4) My Department has reviewed the policy in relation to Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating courses. I have agreed that such courses meet the requirement that all instruction be in English, for the purposes of the GSM program.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 ostensibly a Health portfolio matter; if not, why not; if so, why was it not introduced by the Minister for Health.

(2) Is it his understanding that both the Government and Opposition parties in the House of Representatives and in the Senate have agreed that this bill be determined by a conscience vote; if so, what is his definition of a conscience vote.

(3) Is he aware that on Sunday, 11 August 2002, there was a public meeting at the Wesley Theatrette, 220 Pitt Street Sydney, attended by in excess of one thousand members of the public; if so, has he been issued a transcript or video/audio tape of the proceedings at that meeting.

(4) In light of the overwhelming evidence against the experimentation on human embryos, will he now declare his opposition to this bill and recommend to his parliamentary colleagues and all Members of Parliament in both Houses to do likewise; if not, why not.
(5) Does the bill define the term `human embryo'; if so, is a human embryo a human being; if not, why not.

(6) In introducing the bill, did he state that he could not find a sufficient moral difference between allowing embryos to succumb in this way and destroying them through research that might advance life-saving and life-enhancing therapies.
(7) What life-saving and life-enhancing therapies does he refer to with respect to embryonic stem cell research.

(8) In light of the overwhelming evidence presented by the various speakers at the Wesley Theatrette on 11 August 2002, are the real gains in medical science in the discovery of the life-saving and life-enhancing therapies to be found in adult stem cell research; if not, why not.
(9) Is he able to say which medical, chemical and other corporations have an interest in this bill; if so, who are those corporations and what are their interests.
(10) Which sectors of the Australian and international economy will benefit financially from the introduction of this bill.

(11) Has adult stem cell research demonstrated substantial medical advancements in the treatment of (a) regeneration of tissue from heart attack sufferers, (b) paraplegia from damaged spinal chords, (c) sickle cell anaemia, (d) insulin dependant diabetics, (e) regeneration of immunity systems, (f) eye damage and (g) brain cell re-implantation in the partial treatment of symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Bill is a Health portfolio matter. The Minister for Ageing, the Hon Kevin Andrews MP, has portfolio responsibility for this matter. I introduced the Prohibition of Human Cloning and Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 into the parliament to stand by my commitment to the Council of Australian Governments agreement of 5 April 2002 to introduce Commonwealth legislation by June 2002. The Minister for Health and Ageing has introduced the two new bills, the Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 and the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 into the Senate.

(2) I have allowed the Government a conscience vote on splitting the original Bill and subsequently on the Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 and the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002. I understand that the Opposition did the same. A conscience vote, or a free vote, occurs when a party has no particular policy on a matter or when a party feels that members should be permitted to exercise their responsibility in accordance with their conscience. A conscience vote is one in which a member is able to vote based on his or her own values rather than party lines.
(3) Yes; no transcript or video/audio tape has been drawn to my attention.

(4) No. I support the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 because I do not consider there is a sufficient moral difference between allowing embryos to succumb and destroying them through research and because I have been advised that ongoing research into both adult and embryonic stem cells will allow all potential therapies to be explored. I have allowed a conscience vote on this issue and therefore have not recommended members vote in a particular way.

(5) Yes. Human embryo is defined as a live embryo that has a human genome or an altered human genome and that has been developing for less than 8 weeks since the appearance of 2 pro-nuclei or the initiation of its development by other means. In relation to whether a human embryo is a human being, as I said in my summing up speech of the second reading debate in the House, “there is no one christian tradition that instructs us as to where life starts”.
(6) Yes.

(7) I have been advised that research on both adult stem cell and embryonic stem cells could lead to life-saving and life-enhancing therapies for diseases such as diabetes, Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease.

(8) I am advised that there have been significant developments recently in research using adult stem cells, however, I have also been advised that we need to pursue both embryonic and adult stem cell research to maximise our chances of discovering cures to diseases.
(9) The Bill provides a framework for research. I cannot say what this leads to in terms of the potential interest of medical, chemical or other corporations in subsequent commercial applications.

(10) In finding cures and treatments for disease, medical, scientific and research organisations would be required to carry out extensive research and commit a large amount of resources. Those organisations that do find cures and treatments for disease may benefit financially from their work.

(11) (a) to (g) I understand that a range of studies, in both adult and embryonic stem cells, using both human and animal tissues has demonstrated the potential of stem cells for the development of therapies for a range of diseases.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many breaches of the Sydney Airport curfew have occurred since 1 October 1998.
(2) What are the times and dates of breaches since 1 October 1998.
(3) What is the name of the airline company and type of aircraft responsible for each breach since 1 October 1998.

(4) Have any fines associated with these breaches been visited on the airline companies; if so, what are the full details, including the names of the airline companies and the time and date of each breach incurring a fine; if not, why not.
(5) Will he ensure that all airline companies are fined where a breach of the Sydney Airport curfew occurs which is due to the fault of the airline company; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) There have been nine breaches of the Sydney Airport Curfew since October 1998.
(2) to (4) Details of the nine breaches are as follows:
My Department pursues each breach, depending on advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the outcome of each case, as the Honourable Member is aware, is a matter for the Court's decision.
(5) As indicated in the answer to (4), this is a matter for the Director of Public Prosecutions and the relevant Court.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to objectives 2.1, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.5, 5.1, 5.4 and 6.4 of Australia Cycling: The National Strategy and the attribution of responsibility to the Commonwealth Government for their implementation.
(2) To what extent has development occurred on policies, planning procedures, regulations and initiatives at a Commonwealth level to achieve this strategy aim.
(3) To what extent has development occurred on the creation of an integrated cycling network, within and between communities, and the development of a national standard for such a cycling network.

(4) How many new and renovated public and private developments, including end-of-trip facilities for cyclists, have been undertaken since the commencement of the National Strategy and where are they located.
(5) On which buildings, transport nodes and public places have end-of-trip facilities for cyclists been fitted.

(6) Has development occurred on a national public communication strategy to improve the awareness of all (a) road users on how they can better share roads and (b) path users on how they can better share paths; if so, (i) what is the extent of the development, (ii) has the strategy been implemented and (iii) what measures prove community awareness of the strategy.

(7) Are cycling aspects taken into consideration during road safety audits and blackspot identification; if so, (a) what cycling factors are considered, (b) who is responsible for considering these factors and (c) where is this consideration documented.

(8) Has development occurred on road users behavioural programs or initiatives to improve cyclist safety; if so, (a) what is the extent of the development, (b) how is it being implemented and (c) what measures are there to indicate success.

(9) Has development occurred on a national marketing strategy to promote cycling and its benefits; if so, (a) what is the extent of the development, (b) at what cost to the Commonwealth and (c) what measures are there to indicate success.

(10) Has data been collected and or research commissioned by the Commonwealth providing information to assist decisions made about cycling issues; if so (a) what does the data or research reveal, (b) where can the information be accessed and (c) what cost has been incurred by the Commonwealth in this data collection and research.
(11) What community education programs have been implemented aimed at encouraging adults to cycle and what has been the cost to the Commonwealth of the programmes.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Responsibility for the overall implementation of Australia Cycling, rests primarily with the State, Territory and Local Government authorities, which are best placed to determine local solutions and funding requirements. The Commonwealth also acknowledges a shared responsibility with the States and Territories for some of the strategy's specific objectives. Its contributions to these are coordinated through the Australian Bicycle Council (the Council), which is the body that was established to oversee implementation of the strategy on behalf of all jurisdictions. The Commonwealth also provides the Secretariat to the Australian Bicycle Council.

(2) The Commonwealth continues to support development of policies, regulations, planning and procedures that support the National Strategy through its participation in the Australian Bicycle Council. Relevant portfolios also contribute to policy areas such as road safety and sustainable transport, which support the objectives of the National Strategy. For example the Commonwealth is committed to making improvements to road safety awareness and supports the National Road Safety Strategy 2001 to 2010, which commits all governments (Federal, State and Territory) to achieving better safety outcomes for road users, including cyclists.

The Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTARS) has also arranged for a representative of the Australian Greenhouse Office to provide a presentation on their Travel Demand Programme at the July meeting of the Australian Bicycle Council. This provided an opportunity for the Council to identify synergies between Australia Cycling and activities at the Commonwealth level. In addition DOTARS has also recently amended the Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme so that cyclists are also eligible for a rebate for the costs of shipping their bicycle by ferry between the mainland and Tasmania. This decision supports Objective 2 of Australia Cycling by ensuring cycling is valued appropriately in policies and planning.

(3) The Australian Bicycle Council has been working to highlight the need to develop nationally consistent standards for the use of coloured bicycle lanes and the development of appropriate signage for bicycle paths. The Commonwealth does not have jurisdiction over the development of cycle ways as State, Territory and Local governments are responsible for the planning and regulation of local roadways including cycling networks. However the Commonwealth continues to support the development of policies to support integrated cycle ways through its participation in the Council.

(4) The Commonwealth supports objective 3 of Australia Cycling to promote end-of-trip facilities that encourage increased cycling. However the development of local roads and cycle ways including the establishment end of trip facilities for cyclists are the responsibility of State, Territory and Local governments (in particular Planning and Road Traffic Authorities) and private developers.
(5) The Commonwealth does not keep records of all the buildings in Australia that have end-of-trip facilities for cyclists.

(6) (a) and (b) The Council has determined its priorities for the implementation of the strategy and has at this stage not commenced development of a communication Strategy for road and path users as these objectives are largely being met by State Governments. For example, there have been Share the Road campaigns in SA, WA, QLD and NSW. In addition Bikewest in WA produced a leaflet called 'Using Shared Paths with Courtesy and Safety' and the NT has produced a brochure on cycling on the road which included cyclists rights and obligations on the road and how to use shared paths.

As mentioned above the Commonwealth also supports road safety measures under the National Road Safety Strategy. The aim of the ten-year strategy is to reduce the national road fatality rate by 40% through the implementation of successive National Road Safety Strategy Action Plans. Priority safety measures for cyclists identified in the current 2001 and 2002 Action Plan include targeted promotion of helmet use, support for school-based education programmes and increased cycle paths and lanes.
(7) Yes.

(a) The factors to be considered in the assessment of hazardous road locations are outlined by Austroads, the Association of Australian and New Zealand road transport and traffic authorities, in a range of published guides to traffic engineering practice. Of particular relevance are Austroads' `Road Safety Audit' (Austroads Publication No. AP-30/94 or AP-G30/02), Guide to Traffic Engineering Practice Part 4 - Road Crashes (AP-11.4/88) and Guide to Traffic Engineering Practice Part 14 - Bicycles (AP-11.14/99).
(b) The responsible road authority.
(c) The responsible road authority would typically hold a site assessment and/or Road Safety Audit report.
(8) Yes

(a) The National Road Safety Strategy Action Plan 2001 and 2002 recognises that bicycle safety will benefit from measures aimed more directly at car drivers, such as alcohol control and speed management initiatives. A key example is the progressive introduction of 50 km/h urban speed limits, which is providing improved safety and amenity for cyclists in many jurisdictions.

(b) A proposal to lower the default urban speed limit specified in the Australian National Road Rules to 50 km/h is being developed for submission to Ministers of the Australian Transport Council. The ATSB provided funding of $30,000 in 2000-2001 and advice to assist with the preparation of a comprehensive regulatory impact statement supporting the proposal to introduce 50 km/h urban speed limits.

(c) The success of the National Road Safety Strategy will be based on overall long-term reductions in National Road Toll Statistics. State, Territory and local governments are also undertaking individual programs.
(9) The Council is undertaking a number of actions to market and promote the benefits of cycling including:

· Developing a set of key messages that will be used to promote cycling and its benefits. The messages will target key occupational groups such as the police force, town planners and the members of the health profession;
· Upgrading the Council website to provide more comprehensive progress updates on the status of implementation of the National Strategy and other relevant cycling events;

· The Council is undertaking a study of national cycling data that will assist in identifying cycling trends. Among other things its is expected the outcomes of this study will assist the Council to more effectively target relevant sectors of the community in promoting cycling; and
· Developing a banner stand to be used at the Bicycling Australia Show and future events to promote cycling and the National Strategy.

(b) DOTARS bears the costs of maintaining the Council website and is also funding the development of a banner stand that will be used to promote the National Strategy at the Australian Bicycle Show and relevant events in the future.
(c) The performance measure formally under Strategy 5.1 of Australia Cycling is the community reports increased knowledge about the benefits of cycling.

(10) The Council is undertaking a study of national cycling data to identify and compare trends in bicycle use between states and territories and address inconsistencies in data collection methodologies through the development of appropriate guidelines.
The Australian Transport Safety Bureau also collects national data on bicycle road fatalities to assist policy makers to monitor safety trends for cycling.

(a) The National Cycling Data study indicates some inconsistencies in the data collection methodologies applied between states and thus the results obtained. The Council is developing a discussion paper that will highlight this issue and make recommendations to address this problem in the future.
(b) The ATSB data is published in the Road Fatalities Monthly Bulletin and the Road Fatalities Australia Statistical Summary.

(c) The Commonwealth bears the expense of maintaining the ATSB data on cycling road fatalities. The expense of the National Cycling Data Study is shared by all jurisdictions. However the Commonwealth Department of Health and Ageing provided the funding for the original guidelines.
The Council also undertook a project with Austroads funding to develop guidelines on Forecasting Demand for Cycling Facilities to assist providers in determining future development needs.

(11) Relevant State, Territory and Local government authorities are responsible for community education programmes aimed at encouraging adults to cycle. A key example is the adult riders' course developed by CyclingSouth in conjunction with the Hobart City Council. There are no costs to the Commonwealth associated with such programmes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 348 (Hansard, 27 June 2002, page 4770) concerning ship jumpers, who met the cost of detention and removal of the 18 crew members who deserted their vessels in 2000-2001.

(2) Were there incidents of people jumping ships in 2001-2002; if so, (a) how many people did so, (b) what was the cost of detention and removal of these people, (c) how many of these people lodged immigration applications and (d) what was the (i) nature, (ii) outcome and (iii) country of origin of each applicant.
(3) How many ship jumpers have been granted protection visas each year from 1996-97 and from July 2000 to May 2001, and of these, are there still some in progress and not finalised.

(4) For each of the last 10 financial years, (a) how many ship jumpers were there and (b) what payments under the Migration Act were made by shipping companies for the cost of detention and removal of each ship jumper.

(5) Is there a requirement under the Customs Act to notify his Department of all ship entries and the number of crew on each ship; if not, what action has his Department taken to change this in light of the terrorism attacks of 11 September 2001 and the need to protect Australia's borders.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: In substitution for the answer which appeared in Hansard page 7075 of 23 September 2002:

(1) Shipping companies are responsible for costs associated with removal of crews who desert their vessels. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) does not record data on the cost to each shipping company of detention and removal of deserters.
(2) Yes.
(d) (i) 28 Protection Visa applications; 1 Bridging Visa E (BVE) application; 1 Special Category Visa (SCV) application
(ii) 15 Protection Visa applications refused; 1 BVE granted; 1 SCV granted; all other applications continue to be processed

(iii) Of the persons refused Protection Visas 10 were from Bangladesh, 2 from India, 2 from Iran and 1 from Egypt; the 1 SCV applicant was from New Zealand; the 1 BVE applicant was from Sri Lanka; of the persons whose applications are still being processed 4 are from Iran, 3 from Egypt, 3 from Turkey, 1 from Bangladesh, 1 from Myanmar, and 1 from Pakistan.

(3) Statistical reports on deserters are not available prior to October 2000 when new procedures for the recording of deserters were put in place. Of the persons who deserted ship between July 2000 and May 2001, 1 was granted a protection visa, and there are no unfinalised protection visa applications from that time.
(4) See answer to (3) above.
(a) 2001-02 43 deserters; 2000-01 69 deserters; and 1999-00 65 deserters
(b) DIMIA does not record data on the cost to each shipping company of detention and removal of deserters.

(5) There is no requirement under the Customs Act to notify DIMIA of all ship entries and the number of crew on each ship. However, the Australian Customs Service (ACS) checks details of all crew and passengers on each ship entering Australia against ACS and DIMIA alert lists and reports to DIMIA if there are any persons of concern on the ship. These procedures were in place prior to the events of 11 September 2001, and continue to be enforced.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 August 2002:

question.para: (1) How many actions were exercised by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) under Civil Aviation Regulation 269 (CAR 269) in each of the past five years.
(2) In how many actions was no further action taken.
(3) How many actions resulted in CASA recommendations to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) for further legal action or prosecution action against operators.

(4) Of those recommendations to the DPP for further legal action or prosecutions, how many were proceeded with, and of these, how many resulted in successful prosecutions, failed prosecutions or were withdrawn.
(5) How many were appealed and what was the outcome.
(6) For each prosecution or legal action, what sum was spent by the commonwealth for each case and what was the cost for each agency involved.
(7) For each prosecution or legal action, what sum (a) was recouped from prosecuted operators and (b) did the Commonwealth pay in costs to operators.

(8) With respect to CASA's power to cancel, suspend or vary aviation operators' certificates under CAR 269, what is the internal CASA process taken to establish the veracity of a planned action before it is proceeded with.
(9) At what level of management are decisions under CAR 269 determined.
(10) Is each stage of a planned action recorded; if so, where is the file held and is it subject to Freedom of Information procedures; if not, why not.
(11) Does the decision making process assess the impact of an action under CAR 269 on the reputation or viability of an operator, or is safety the only consideration.

(12) If an action is not proceeded with, or is subsequently stopped or withdrawn, does CASA apologise to the operator or issue any public notice advising that the action will not proceed and offer reasons why; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice.

(1) The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) does not centrally record each action exercised by CASA under Civil Aviation Regulation (CAR) 269. To extract the requested information would require a review of each action commenced by the CASA within the last five years to determine if the action was exercised using CAR 269. CASA is unable therefore to provide the requested information without a significant input of resources.
(2) See 1 above.
(3) Over the five-year period, 123 matters were referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP).

(4) Over the five-year period the DPP commenced prosecution action in 67 matters. 21 matters were withdrawn and 58 convictions were recorded. These figures do not amount to 67 referred actions, as some matters that are recorded as being finalised during the period were in fact referred to the DPP prior to the 5-year period. Similarly, some matters that are recorded as being referred to the DPP during the 5-year period are still awaiting assessment. The situation is summarised below.
* Figures for 2002 are for the period 1 Jan to 31 July 2002
(5) Appeals are handled by the DPP. CASA does not maintain records of the outcome in these cases.
(6) (7) Costs of prosecutions and other DPP action are matters for the DPP.

(8) Action to cancel, suspend or vary Air Operator's Certificates is not taken under CAR 269. Such action is taken under sections 28BA, 28BB and 28BC of the Civil Aviation Act. The process followed by the Authority when cancelling, suspending or cancelling an Air Operator's Certificate is detailed in the Compliance and Enforcement Manual. This manual is available on the CASA website at wwww.casa.gov.au.
(9) Delegations under CAR 269 are restricted to General Manager, or higher, level.

(10) Yes. Each stage is recorded on a CASA In-Confidence file at the office where the action was commenced. The General Manager, General Aviation Operations also commences a CASA In-Confidence file in the event the action results in a recommendation to the General Manager for cancellation, suspension or variation of the licence against which the action was commenced.
CASA records are subject to Freedom of Information procedures in accordance with the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act.

(11) CASA is required to exercise its powers and perform its functions in accordance with the requirements of the Civil Aviation Act 1988. Under sub-section 9A(1) of the Act, CASA must regard the safety of air navigation as the most important consideration when exercising its powers and performing its functions.

(12) Before taking action under CAR 269, CASA is required to issue a Show Cause notice. CAR 269 requires that the person receiving a Show Cause notice be given a reasonable opportunity to show cause why CASA should not take the proposed action.
In the event that a person provides acceptable reasons why it would be inappropriate for CASA to take the proposed action, CASA will not proceed with the action.
CASA will advise the person of its decision and the reasons for the decision.

This process is not a public process and CASA does not generally publicise that it has issued a Show Cause notice to a person. It would therefore be inappropriate for CASA to issue any public notice that it is not proceeding with a particular show cause action.
Whether or not CASA apologises to the person concerned depends upon the circumstances of each case.

subdebateinfo.title: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts: Staffing

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 20 August 2002:

question.para: (1) How many (a) full time permanent staff, (b) part time permanent staff, (c) full time contract staff and (d) part time contract staff were employed by (i) the Minister's Department and (ii) agencies within the Minister's portfolio as at (A) 30 March 1996 and (B) 30 June 2002.

(2) For each category of engagement referred to in part (1) and employed by (a) the Minister's Department and (b) agencies within the Minister's portfolio, where were such persons located in (i) 30 March 1996 and (ii) 30 June 2002.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The information sought in relation to part (1)(A) and part (2)(i) of his question is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the use of the resources that would be required to provide that information. I am able to inform the honourable member, however, that data on Australian Public Service staffing as at 30 June 1996 is contained in the Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin 1995-1996, which is publicly available.

The honourable member should be aware, however, that changes in APS functions and administrative arrangements between 1996 and 2002 may render direct comparisons between the data for those years invalid.
In relation to the answers provided:
- `contract staff' is taken to mean `non-ongoing staff';
- `full time permanent staff' is taken to mean `ongoing, full time staff';
- `part time permanent staff' is taken to mean `ongoing, part time staff';
- `full time contract staff' is taken to mean `non-ongoing, full time staff'; and
- `part time contract staff' is taken to mean `non-ongoing, part time staff'.
In answer to parts (1)(B) and (2)(ii):
- Table 1 shows the number of staff in the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) on 30 June 2002; and
- Table 2 shows the number of staff in portfolio Commonwealth Authorities, as defined in section 7 of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, on 30 June 2002.

Note: These figures include staff on the AFFA payroll system working in the areas of Plant Breeders Rights Advisory Committee, National Residue Survey, Australian Plague Locust Commission, National Rural Advisory Council, Australian Landcare Council and the Dairy Adjustment Authority.

entry.para: AFFA Commonwealth Authorities Staffing as at 30 June 2002
Forest and Wood Product R&D Corporation
Land and Water Resources R&D Corporation

answer.para: In addition to the above, the Dairy Adjustment Authority office in Melbourne had 19 employees at 30 June 2002. That number comprised 9 full-time ongoing and 1 part time ongoing staff seconded from the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) as well as 10 full-time non-ongoing staff. There were also two permanent full time staff in Canberra, who were full-time ongoing staff of AFFA and are therefore included in the first table.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister been contacted by Freedom Air in relation to a proposal to conduct flights from New Zealand to Maroochydore Airport; if so, when and what was the Minister's response.
(2) What aviation and customs related charges are imposed by the Commonwealth or Commonwealth agencies on a foreign airline landing at Maroochydore airport.
(3) How do these costs compare with the costs for a foreign airline to conduct the same flights to Brisbane airport or Cairns airport.
(4) Are there any infrastructure, technical or policy barriers to the operation of foreign airline operations to Maroochydore airport; if so, what are they and what sum would they cost to provide.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) Aviation charges imposed on airlines by Airservices Australia at Maroochydore Airport are for Terminal Navigation Charges (TNC) only. The cost for international and domestic services are the same.
(3) Airservices Australia has advised that charges for B737-300 aircraft (56,740 kg maximum take off weight) at Maroochydore, Brisbane and Cairns airports are as follows:

entry.para: Airservices Terminal Navigation Charge (TNC) Charge per tonne landed (incl GST)
Airservices Aviation Rescue and Fire Fighting (ARFF) Charge per tonne landed (Incl GST)

answer.para: (4) From the perspective of the Department of Transport and Regional Services there are no policy barriers to the operation by foreign airlines of international flights to Maroochydore Airport. In respect to the rights of foreign airlines to operate international flights to Maroochydore, the Government's regional package allows unrestricted access to regional international airports. The regional package is being included progressively in air services arrangements with our bilateral partners.

Airports may be designated as international where facilities are available for the formalities incident to customs, immigration, quarantine and other requirements in connection with the arrival in or departure from Australian territory of aircraft. The provision of such facilities is a matter for discussion between these agencies, the airport operator and the airline.

Prior to commencement of any international services, Maroochydore Airport would be required to discuss implementing a checked baggage screening program with the Department of Transport and Regional Services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 21 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the productivity level of 25 Ukranian seafarers is equivalent to that of 17 Australian seafarers aboard the CSL Yarra.
(2) Is it detrimental to Australia's security to have Australian merchant ships crewed by foreign seafarers.
(3) In times of conflict would Australia's economic independence be affected without an Australian flagged and crewed fleet.
(4) Did Australia use foreign ships to take personnel and materiel to East Timor in 1999; if so, why.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) CSL makes the commercial decisions in respect of the number of crew and its productivity. CSL, like other ship operators, are required to meet international standards of safety and marine environment protection. The port state control program administered by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority is aimed at ensuring compliance with those standards.

(2) Merchant ships with foreign crew members come to Australia to carry our international trade. The Government is working with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) on developing an International Ship and Port Facility (ISPS) Code. This will mean that all ships and ports involved in international trade will be subject to strong security measures, and those that are not compliant with the Code will be prevented from trading.
(3) On all advice to me, no.

(4) The logistics for the East Timor operation were organised by the Department of Defence. I am advised, however, that both Australian and foreign vessels were used according to the capability and availability of the vessels for the requisite tasks on a strictly commercial basis.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 August 2002:

question.para: (1) What are the revenue implications for the Commonwealth of the decision of the North West Shelf Venture partners to allow the China National Offshore Oil Company equity in the project.
(2) What are the revenue implications for the Commonwealth of the decision to give China exclusive rights to ship liquefied natural gas from Australia to China.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The decisions of the North West Shelf Venture partners to allow the China National Offshore Oil Company (CNOOC) to take equity in the project and participate in shipping LNG arise from a commercial agreement. The Government is not party to the agreement and therefore cannot quantify the revenue implications.

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 330 (Hansard, 20 August 2002, page 5164) concerning planned expenditure on the Roads of National Importance Program, for each year from 2001-2002 to 2005-2006 what projects will be undertaken in each State and Territory.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 17 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Physical Address Register Verification Project involve Australian Electoral Commission staff physically verifying possible enrolment addresses by visiting every street in each electoral division.
(2) Has work been undertaken in the electoral division of Wills; if so, what percentage has been completed; if not, when will it be completed.
(3) How frequently is the addresses register updated in the electoral division of Wills.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Physical Address Register Verification Project does involve Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) staff physically verifying addresses. However, the AEC has not undertaken to visit every address in each division. A pilot Physical Address Register Verification exercise was undertaken in Tasmania resulting in a recommendation that only addresses with street numbering be considered for verification in this manner. Some verification work has also been undertaken in New South Wales and Western Australia. The AEC will be undertaking an evaluation of the Physical Address Register Verification before deciding whether to extend the process nationally.
(2) No Physical Address Register Verification work has been undertaken in the Division of Wills and at this stage there are no plans or funding to undertake this exercise in the immediate future.

(3) The Address Register is updated in every Division, including the Division of Wills, every time an enrolment form is received for an address that is not included on the Address Register. However, new addresses are only added after the address has been checked as being valid. In most cases, divisions would up date the Address Register each day.

(4) Refer Attachment B.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Which members of the Federal Parliament have made visits to Taiwan in the last 10 years?
(2) What was the purpose of each visit?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Based on records held by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the following is a list of Federal parliamentarians who have visited Taiwan in the last 3 years. Providing data beyond 3 years solely for the purpose of answering the honourable member's question would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved.

entry.para: Parliamentary delegation led by the Hon. Kevin Andrews, and including Senator John Quirke, Senator Julian McGauran, Senator Ross Lightfoot and Mr Jim Lloyd MP
To support the development of economic and other people-to-people contacts with Taiwan.
Parliamentary delegation led by Senator the Hon. Paul Calvert, and including Senator the Hon. Helen Coonan, Mr Andrew Thompson MP, the Hon. Gary Hardgrave MP, Mr Bob Secombe MP and Mr Harry Quick MP
The Hon. Mark Vaile MP, Minister of Trade
To promote trade and economic links with Taiwan.
Members of the Australia-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, including Senators Alan Ferguson, Senator Jeannie Ferris, Senator Joe Ludwig, Senator John Hogg and Senator Steven Hutchins
To support the development of economic and other people-to-people contacts with Taiwan.
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator the Hon. Ron Boswell
To attend the 17th Joint Australia-Taiwan Business Councils Meeting.
Parliamentary delegation led by the Hon. Alex Somlyay MP, including the Hon. Janice Crosio MP, Mr Harry Jenkins MP, Mr Harry Quick MP and Mr Alby Schultz MP
To support the development of economic and other people-to-people contacts with Taiwan.
To support the development of economic and other people-to-people contacts with Taiwan.

answer.para: (2) As listed above.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Defence Housing Authority
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 961)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Defence Housing Authority (DHA) planning to make substantial special dividends to the Government instead of improving stock numbers, quality of housing and improvements in singles accommodation; if so, why.
(2) Has $84 million in DHA property value been surrendered to the Government for the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust.
(3) What difficulties are anticipated as DHA disengages from pre-1996 leases and what strategies are and will be implemented to overcome these difficulties.
(4) How many staff does DHA employ, what is the State and Territory breakdown of that staff and what was the corresponding figure for each of the previous 6 years.
(5) When is it anticipated to present the proposed amendments to the DHA legislation to Parliament.

(6) What are the anticipated risks in the over-reliance on private investor leasing arrangements and what contingencies have been implemented to cover these risks and ensure they are properly managed.
(7) What are the salary levels of the Chairman and Director of the DHA and what are the individual areas of expertise they bring to DHA.

(8) Is she aware of the concerns of Australian Defence Force families about the continued run down of DHA owned housing stock and what is the Government doing to either halt the run down or address these concerns.
(9) What are the repair and maintenance budgets for DHA housing for each financial year from 1999-2000.

(10) How many individual business units exist within DHA and for each, (a) where they are located, (b) how many staff does each have, (c) how many clients does each serve and (d) are they run as separate organisational delivery and profit centres; if so, how (i) are they managed and (ii) are profits distributed.
(11) Will she table a copy of the services agreement with her Department under which it is claimed price and risk sharing arrangements, services and payments are being made.

(12) Given that the total value of properties being managed by DHA on behalf of Defence is approximately $3.8 billion, of which $1.4 billion is owned by DHA, what is the breakdown of ownership of the remaining $2.4 billion.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (2) Yes

(3) DHA seeks to convert 30% of pre-1996 leases to post-1996 leases and replace the remainder of houses required by new stock. The main problem that could arise would be an inability to persuade sufficient lessors. Should this occur, DHA will increase its plans to acquire new stock including direct leasing and increase reliance on rental allowances.
(4) 658 staff as at 30 June 2002. The distribution of staff members by State and Territory, and the corresponding figures for previous years were:
* Note: ACT staff numbers include Head Office employees
(5) It is not possible at this time to indicate a time frame for their presentation to Parliament.

(6) Over reliance on private investor leasing would increase DHA's risk of not having access to sufficient properties in the event that lessors refuse to renew the leases. DHA mitigates this risk by owning certain properties close to military bases where land is not available to replace the houses, and by continually reviewing its reliance on private investor leasing in the light of demand and market conditions.
(7) Salary details for Directors are determined and published by the Remuneration Tribunal. Profiles of Directors are published in the DHA Annual Report.

(8) DHA regularly consults the Australian Defence Force families on housing needs and it is represented on the DHA Board by the Defence Families of Australia Convener. DHA is continually improving the quality of its stock and its planned increased reliance on private investors through the Sale and Leaseback Program is important in this regard. DHA modifies its risk as indicated in 6 above.
(10) Business Units within DHA:
(a) Defence member services:
· Tenancy Management
· Property Management
· Relocation Services
· Home Owner
(b) Sales and Development.
(c) Investment Management.

All business operations are managed through DHA's Head Office located in Canberra with regional operations carried out through regionally based Housing Management Centres. As the majority of DHA staff carry out activities for each business line, staff numbers by business line cannot be provided. These business lines are run as profit centres, however, dividend distributions to the Government are made out of DHA's consolidated corporate results rather than from the business lines.
(11) No. The document is Commercial-In-Confidence.
(12) The ownership of the $2.4 billion of stock under management is by private investors who lease their houses to DHA on long-term lease arrangements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

question.para: (1) What was the level of partial and radical breast mastectomy in terms of (a) the number and (b) percentage of total breast cancer patients in (i) 1996, (ii) 1997, (iii) 1998, (iv) 1999, (v) 2000 and (vi) 2001 on a national and State and Territory basis.

(2) What was the level of breast reconstruction in terms of (a) the number and (b) percentage of total breast cancer patients in (i) 1996, (ii) 1997, (iii) 1998, (iv) 1999, (v) 2000 and (vi) 2001 on a national and State and Territory basis.

(3) What were the waiting times for breast prostheses or forms for patients following a partial or radical mastectomy in (i) 1996 (ii) 1997 (iii) 1998 (iv) 1999 (v) 2000 and (vi) 2001 on a national and State and Territory basis.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The most recent data specifically on the number of mastectomies can be derived from the National Hospital Morbidity Database, which provides information about the number of breast mastectomies and all subclassifications for the years 1996-2000. The data collection focuses on hospital procedures rather than individual patients.
The following table gives nationally the total number of mastectomy procedures performed, for separations with a diagnosis of primary or secondary neoplasm of the breast (female breast cancer only):
From the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare.
Additional data can be found at the following website: www.aihw.gov.au. Data from the year 2001 is not yet available.

(b) (i-v) Data published in Surgical management of breast cancer in Australia in 1995 (Hill et al.) found that approximately 49 per cent of women with breast cancer had mastectomy surgery. Women with early breast cancer from non-urban areas were more likely to have a mastectomy (54 per cent) compared to women with early breast cancer from urban areas (44 per cent). This is the only comprehensive published national data available on breast cancer treatment patterns. It describes each incident of breast cancer notified to cancer registries throughout Australia between April and September 1995.
(b) (vi) A direct request would need to be made to each State and Territory cancer registry to obtain any data broken down by State and Territory classification.

(2) (a) The most recent data on the number of breast reconstructions can be derived from the National Hospital Morbidity Database, which provides information about the number of general breast reconstructions for the years 1996-2000. Some of the coding systems in use, however, do not specify breast reconstruction following mastectomy. The data are available on a national basis, through the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare at www.aihw.gov.au. Data for the year 2001 is not yet available.

(b) (i-v) Data published in Surgical management of breast cancer in Australia in 1995 (Hill et al.) shows women under 50 years of age were more likely to have breast conserving surgery compared with women over 50 years of age. Fifteen per cent of women under 50 years of age with early breast cancer were planning to have or had had a reconstruction. Four per cent of women 50 years of age and over with early breast cancer were planning to have, or have had a reconstruction. Women with early breast cancer from urban areas were more likely to have breast-conserving surgery
(56 per cent) compared to women with early breast cancer in non-urban areas

(46 per cent). This is the only comprehensive published national data available, describing each incident of breast cancer notified to cancer registries throughout Australia between April and September 1995.
(b) (vi) A direct request would need to be made to each State and Territory cancer registry to obtain the data on a State and Territory basis.

(3) (i-vi) National data on waiting times for breast prostheses or forms for patients are not collected. State and Territories are responsible for the provision of breast prostheses and a direct request would need to be made to each State and Territory to obtain the information requested.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Are members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) unable to get employment in other Government agencies until they have received a discharge certificate.
(2) Is it a fact that in the past members of the ADF could take long service leave and complete police training, then discharge or return to the ADF if their police training was unsuccessful.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Section 20 of the Public Service Act 1999 confers on each Agency Head the rights, duties and powers of an employer with respect to APS employees within that Agency. Therefore, within the legal framework supplied by the PS Act, each Agency Head is able to establish certain conditions of employment and service for the Agency's employees.

It is not known what policies other Commonwealth agencies may have implemented with respect to engaging ex ADF personnel in APS positions prior to discharge from full time service becoming effective. In Defence, up until 29 April 2002, it was possible for a discharging ADF member to be engaged in an APS position before the member's discharge became effective. The member could proceed on paid leave to commence civilian employment while the discharge was being processed. However the policy was changed on the decision of the Secretary and the Chief of the Defence Force, because the Commonwealth Ombudsman questioned the probity of the arrangement whereby an ADF member could be doubly accruing certain Commonwealth employment benefits.

If other Commonwealth agencies have implemented similar policies it is because of decisions made within their respective agencies - it is not possible for Defence to impose its policy on other Agencies as each has certain autonomy with respect to employment within the legal framework.

(2) I am unable to comment on the employment practices of the various police agencies, both at the State and Federal level. However, members of the ADF have certain obligations under Defence Instruction (General) (DI(G)) Personnel (PERS) 25-2 Employment and Voluntary Activities of Australian Defence Force Members in Off-Duty Hours requiring all ADF members to seek prior approval from their commander before engaging in outside employment in off-duty hours, including during periods of leave. A permanent member of the ADF who is on long service leave, must obtain approval in writing in accordance with DI(G) PERS 25-2 before engaging in paid employment outside the ADF in off-duty hours.

The policy lists those occasions where approval is not normally to be given, for example, where the employment would create a conflict of interest with the member's public duty, where it would interfere with the member's efficiency or where the employment could bring the ADF into disrepute.

ADF members, upon fulfilling their obligations under DI(G) PERS 25-2 Employment and Voluntary Activities of Australian Defence Force Members in Off-Duty Hours, would be able to engage in employment dependant upon the employment practices of the engaging organisation. Of course, ADF members are entitled to return to Defence once their long service leave has expired.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (8) of question No. 610 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 6800), does the privatisation of Sydney Airport mean that there is now commercial pressure to relinquish statutory controls over aircraft movements during both curfew and non-curfew periods at that airport; if so, what is that pressure from the airport lessee company or any other person; if not, why not.

(2) Is the same commercial pressure on non-aeronautical services at Sydney Airport that led to the elimination of the pricing surveillance regulatory regime at that airport, the same commercial pressure that will see the aircraft movement and hence the aircraft noise regulatory regime weakened in the future.
(3) Does the net effect of privatisation of ownership of Sydney Airport mean the taking away of public ownership of the direct management of Sydney Airport as both landlord and land manager.

(4) Does taking away effective management and land interest at Sydney Airport mean the loss of the most effective environmental management device of all, that is, actual ownership of the land; if not, why not.

(5) With the passing of title in the airport lease to a private company, is the ability to effectively manage Sydney Airports aircraft noise problems relinquished with the passing of that title; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The sale of the airport does not change the Government's aircraft movement cap or noise management policies in any way - the Government retains full regulatory control. Sydney Airport will continue to be subject to the 80 aircraft movements per hour planning cap, the curfew from 11pm to 6am and the noise sharing policy implemented through the Sydney Airport Long Term Operating Plan.

(2) The Productivity Commission was asked in December 2000 to examine whether there was an ongoing need for price regulation of airports. The Commission's final report was provided to the Government on 25 January 2002. The Government accepted the Commission's recommendation that Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Canberra and Darwin airports be subject to price monitoring for five years commencing 1 July 2002. The Government has reserved the right to reimpose price controls if it is found that airport operators were abusing their market power by unjustifiably raising prices. See also the answer to (1) above.

(3) and (4) As a leased Federal airport, Sydney Airport remains a Commonwealth place and continues to be subject to the provisions of the Airports Act 1996. The Act is the basis of a comprehensive regulatory regime for land use, planning, building controls and environmental management, which is administered by the Commonwealth.
(5) No. See answer to (1) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) In his responses to part (2) of question No. 629 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 6802) and part (8) of question No. 610 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 6800) did he state that he has given an assurance that the Government had no intention of changing its noise policy and residents of Sydney could be confident that the sale of Sydney Airport will not change the Governments noise policy in any way but states that a Government cannot bind the actions of a future government; if so, are these statements contradictory.

(2) If so, is it a fact that he cannot and could never give, such an assurance as no Minister nor any Government can bind the actions of a future Government, including this current Government; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The Government's aircraft noise policy in relation to Sydney Airport was clearly stated at the time of the Airport's sale.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen a report by Mark Metherell titled “Medibank loss comes at a 13% premium” on page 3 of the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 September 2002.

(2) Do many members of Medibank Private face a premium increase of up to 6%, taking the average increase to about 13% for the year, following the Government's decision to allow the fund to cut discounts; if not, why not.
(3) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statement by Nicola Ballenden of the Australian Consumers' Association that the discount cuts were a premium increase by any other name.
(4) Why did Medibank Private make a record $175 million dollar loss in the last financial year.
(5) Can the Minister guarantee that the Government will not sell Medibank Private; if so, how; if not, why not.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Medibank Private estimates that 95% of its members (2,650,929) will be affected by the removal of discounts of between 4% and 6%.
(3) Yes.
(4) Medibank Private released their Annual Report for the financial year 2001-02 on 27 September 2002. This document is available publicly and contains full disclosure of their financial results.

(5) The Minister for Finance and Administration is responsible for the scoping study on the possible sale of Medibank Private as announced in the 2002-03 Budget. The Government has not made any decision to sell Medibank Private.

subdebateinfo.title: Employer Nomination Scheme for Cardiothoracic Surgeons
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 988)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 14 October 2002:

question.para: (1) How many applications have been received under the Employer Nomination Scheme for Cardiothoracic Surgeons over the past 2 years.
(2) What checks has his Department carried out to verify that Australian trained graduates were not available to fill the positions which were the subject of the nominations.
(3) Is he aware that qualified Australian cardiothoracic surgeons cannot obtain employment with Australian hospitals in their specialist field.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In the 2000-01 and 2001-02 financial years and the first quarter of 2002-03 the Department approved six nominations under the Employer Nomination Scheme for specialist surgeons. The five occupations covered by the six nominations were Neurosurgeon, Orthopaedic Surgeon, Burns Injury Specialist, Associate Surgeon (specialising in abdominal surgery) and Associate Professor of Surgery. Nominations for cardiothoracic surgeons, if there were any under the Employer Nomination Scheme, do not appear to have been recorded as such during 2000-02 or 2002-03 to date. It is possible cardiothoracic surgeons may have entered under other categories, including non-skill related categories such as spouses.

(2) Under the Employer Nomination Scheme, labour market testing of the vacant position is required unless the occupation is in short supply at a national level. Occupations on the Migration Occupation in Demand List (MODL) therefore do not require labour market testing. Under this visa class, certification from state or territory health authorities that the occupation is in shortage such as in an “area of need” is required. Labour market testing generally involves placing advertisements in metropolitan and national newspapers and relevant professional journals and lodgement of the position with a Job Network member or other large recruitment agency. The labour market testing must be undertaken in the six months immediately before lodging the nomination. The employer must provide documentary evidence of the labour market testing undertaken, details of any unsuccessful applicants and reasons for not selecting each of the persons.
(3) The Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee reported on “The Cardiothoracic Surgery Workforce in Australia - Supply and Requirements 2000-2011” in April 2001. The report concluded that:

“the cardiothoracic surgery workforce is adequately meeting current requirements. To ensure requirements continue to be met, the Working Party recommends that the number of trainees entering the advanced cardiothoracic surgery trainee program be maintained at approximately five per year. In recent years an average of five trainees graduated from the training program each year.”

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 15 October 2002:

question.para: (1) What is the Government doing to arrest the critical shortages of doctors in the outer metropolitan areas of Melbourne.
(2) What incentives will the Government provide doctors to locate in Melton and Sunbury.
(3) What assistance will be provided to existing medical services to enable them to attract sufficient doctors.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The 2002-03 Federal Budget allocated $80 million over four years to establish the More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas Measure to increase the number of medical practitioners working in the outer metropolitan areas of the six State capital cities. Three programs were outlined to meet the Government's commitment to outer metropolitan areas. These were:

· allowing specialist trainees and medical researchers to work in supervised general practice programs in outer-metropolitan areas under the Outer Metropolitan Workforce Shortage (Specialist Trainees and Medical Researchers) Program;

· requiring doctors undertaking the `general stream' of the general practice training program to undertake a placement in designated outer-metropolitan areas as part of the Outer Metropolitan GP Registrars Program; and

· allowing non-vocationally recognised medical practitioners who undertake a vocational recognition program and who agree to work in designated outer metropolitan areas to become eligible for higher Medicare rebates as part of the Outer Metropolitan (Other Medical Practitioners) Relocation Incentive Program.
The first two programs are scheduled for implementation in early 2003, while the third program is scheduled for implementation later this year.
(2) Practices in both Melton and Sunbury will be eligible for the More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas Measure.

(3) The Department will be writing to all known eligible practices under the More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas Measure, informing them of the three programs and providing details on how they can participate.

It is proposed that assistance will be provided to eligible practices to help locate eligible medical practitioners. The Department also proposes to provide eligible medical practices with suitable support to facilitate a smooth transition for new doctors to outer metropolitan practices. These support arrangements are being developed in conjunction with established medical organisations.

In addition, practices in the designated outer metropolitan areas will be eligible for assistance to become Royal Australian College of General Practitioner accredited training practices, which will encourage more practices in areas of doctor shortage to participate in the training of General Practice Registrars.
