talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Director-General Reserves - Navy unable to continue forwarding gratis copies of Navy/Reserve News to former members of the Navy Reserve.
(2) If this decision has been made due to budgetary constraints, what are these constraints.
(3) Were other funding measures considered before the subscription fee was introduced.
(4) If other funding measures were considered, what were they and why were they not implemented.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Gratis copies of Navy/Reserve News will continue to be forwarded to all Navy Reserve members, both active and inactive. This arrangement is discontinued once Naval Reserve members retire from the Naval Reserve or otherwise cease to be a Naval Reserve member, with the exception that a limited number of retired senior officers have received and will continue to receive complementary copies. Copies of Navy/Reserve News are otherwise available to any member of the public, including former Naval Reserve members, by subscription.
(2) There have been some recent budgetary considerations associated with Reserve News distribution. These are as follows:

(a) Prior to 28 May 2001 Reserve News was produced and mailed out to Naval Reserve members on a four-weekly basis. From this date, Reserve News was produced fortnightly, together with the fortnightly produced Navy News and mailed-out fortnightly.

(b) In December 2001, production of Reserve News reverted to a four-weekly cycle, but a fortnightly mail-out to Naval Reserve members continued, with a copy of Reserve News being included with every second edition of Navy News.

(c) In an effort to rein in the increased distribution costs of a fortnightly mail-out, a four-weekly mail-out containing two consecutive issues of Navy News (one of which includes Reserve News), commenced in September 2002.

(d) The initial fortnightly mail-out did result in a greater than planned draw down of available FY 2002/03 Reserve News funds, requiring some internal re-allocation. This re-allocation has been made and production and distribution of Reserve News for the remainder of FY 2002/03 on the basis described in sub-paragraph (c) above is assured.

(3) A subscription fee for Navy/Reserve News only applies in the circumstance outlined in paragraph (1). This has always been the case. Means to provide a wider gratis distribution of Reserve News to the community generally and to employers is currently being investigated. This is in line with the recent Government initiated program of enhancements to the Australian Defence Force Reserves.
(4) As it is not planned to introduce a general gratis distribution of Navy/Reserve News to former Naval Reserve members, no additional funding measures are necessary for this purpose.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 21 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) Which postcodes or suburbs fall within the South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region of Perth.
(2) On the most recent data, how many residential aged care beds are there in South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region of Perth.
(3) On the most recent data, how many high care and low care residential beds are there in each of the postcodes or suburbs in the South-East Metropolitan Care Planning Region of Perth.
(4) On the most recent data, how many of these high care and low care beds, in each of the postcodes or suburbs, are in use.

(5) On the most recent data, how many high care and low care beds, in each of the postcodes or areas, have been allocated to the South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region and are yet to be occupied.
(6) Is he aware that 50% of older Australians have to wait more than 1 month and 25% have to wait 3 months or longer to enter a residential aged care home; if not, why not.
(7) In each postcode or suburb in the South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region of Perth, how long do people have to wait for a residential aged care place.

(8) Does he intend to implement a key recommendation of the 2001 Two Year Review of Aged Care Reforms and review the indicators of demand for residential and community care; if so, when; if not, why not.
(9) Is it government policy that Australians who require residential aged care should be able to access this care in their local community; if not, why not.
(10) Can he explain in detail what he means when he states that one of the Government's major priorities in aged care is to ensure that older Australians are able to access residential aged care.

(11) Do Australians residing in the postcodes of 6108, 6107, 6109 and 6110 in the City Of Gosnells in Perth have to move to the postcode areas of 6151 and 6100, some 30 minutes away by car within the South-East Planning Region, to access residential aged care beds; if so why.
(12) Is it important for aged people requiring care to be able to access that care within their own local community; if not, why not.
(13) Will he rectify the problem of the shortage of residential aged care beds in the City of Gosnells; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) As postcodes and suburbs can overlap Aged Care Planning Regions they are not used in the calculation of aged care provision in a region. An aged care home which is in one postcode area may not be part of the same Aged Care Planning Region as other homes in the same postcode area. Aged Care Planning Regions are based on groupings of Statistical Local Areas (SLAs). In answering the question, place numbers in each SLA will be provided.

The SLAs that make up Metropolitan South East Aged Care Planning Region, Western Australia, are: Armadale (C), Belmont (C), Canning (C), Gosnells (C), Serpentine - Jarrahdale (S), South Perth (C) and Victoria Park (T).
(2) At 30 June 2002 the total number of allocated residential aged care places in Metropolitan South East was 2,909.
(3) Allocated Aged Care Places by SLA. June 2002
(4) Operational Aged Care Places by SLA. June 2002
(5) Provisionally Allocated Aged Care Places by SLA. June 2002

(6) The Department of Health and Ageing does not collect or keep information on waiting period, the length of time from the date a person chooses or actively seeks to enter residential aged care and the date they actually enter residential aged care. The Department does keep information on entry period, the period of time elapsed between the date a person receives an Aged Care Assessment Team (ACAT) approval for eligibility to enter residential aged care and the date the person actually enters an aged care home.

There are a number of factors that impact on the period of time that elapses between the date a person receives an ACAT approval for eligibility to enter residential aged care and the date the person actually enters an aged care home.

In May 2002 the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW) published a report, Entry Period for Residential Aged Care. The report is a statistical analysis of the elapsed time between an assessment of eligibility for residential aged care and the date of actual entry to residential aged care. The report examines but rejects the use of entry period as a proxy for waiting time and, by implication, as a measure of the accessibility of aged care services. The analysis shows that the supply of services in any particular region has a negligible effect on entry period.

An important determinant of a short entry period, the AIHW found, is whether the resident had an ACAT assessment performed in hospital rather than when they were living at home. A longer entry period is also strongly related to whether the resident had previously used a Community Aged Care Package (CACP) or residential respite care.

As part of the 1997 Aged Care Structural Reforms, the validity of an ACAT approval for high care admission was extended from ninety days to one year. People do not have to act immediately following ACAT approval for admission to residential care. They have time to visit different homes, consider their options, settle their affairs and make arrangements with the home of their choice before they enter care. As the AIHW report confirmed, increased availability of community care and respite care has a significant effect in delaying entry to permanent care. People are able to remain in the community for longer after they have been assessed by an ACAT as eligible for residential care. On average, recipients of CACPs remained in the community fifteen months longer than other residents did before they entered residential care. Similarly, respite care recipients remained in the community longer.
(7) See answer to question six.

(8) The Department continues to implement this recommendation. The above-mentioned AIHW report is part of this process. The AIHW was contracted in October 2001 to undertake a multivariate statistical analysis of entry periods to residential aged care. The AIHW was also asked to comment on whether `entry period' is a robust performance indicator of accessibility for the aged care system.
As mentioned above, this report was published in May 2002.
(9) Yes.

(10) The Commonwealth Government is committed to ensuring that frail older Australians have reasonable access to quality residential and community care which will enable them to live in dignity. To ensure an equitable distribution of residential aged care places and CACPs, the Government uses a comprehensive planning framework which aims to provide 100 residential aged care places and CACPs for every 1,000 people aged seventy years and over. This benchmark helps achieve a more equitable distribution of places to regions. This planning framework applies across the whole of Australia in both city and country areas.

(11) People assessed as eligible for residential aged care base their choice of an aged care home on a number of factors. These factors include whether an aged care home offers extra services, the location of an aged care home in relation to family or friends, and the accreditation and certification status of an aged care home.
(12) Yes. Refer to the answer to question ten.

(13) Metropolitan South East Aged Care Planning Region has an aged care which exceeds the benchmark figure of 100 residential aged care places and CACPs for every 1,000 people aged seventy years and over.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 October 2002:

question.para: (1) How many currently serving Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel have been injured undertaking fitness tests since 1998.
(2) What measures have been introduced to prevent the loss of experienced ADF members with 6 years or more service due to injury associated with fitness testing.
(3) Have new fitness tests been introduced for Defence force job applicants.
(4) Will the new fitness standards preclude some women from military roles that they currently perform.
(5) Will the new fitness standards open the way for women to enter into combat roles provided they meet the fitness requirements.
(6) Have changes to medical and fitness requirements for instructors involved in the cadet scheme resulted in losses of experienced staff.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Injuries related to physical fitness testing in the ADF are not recorded separately and are therefore not available.
(2) No specific information is available to suggest that there has been a loss of experienced ADF members as a result of injury associated with fitness testing.

(3) All ADF applicants are required to pass a physical fitness assessment (PFA) prior to enlistment. The PFA for the Army was introduced in 1997 and for the Navy and the Air Force in August 2001. The introduction of minimum fitness standards has been a significant factor in the marked reduction in injury rates in recruit training units.

(4) A Physical Employment Standards Project is currently underway. The aim is to analyse the ergonomic, human performance and physical capacity requirements for all combat arms in order to develop gender-free, task-based, physical employment standards. The key outcomes are to reduce injuries, provide a more direct linkage of training strategies to the actual tasks being undertaken and inform a range of human resource activities. Until the study is completed and the data analysed no consideration of the possible exclusion of either male or female personnel who do not meet these physical employment standards will be undertaken.

(5) Physical competencies are not the only factors that need to be taken into account when considering women for combat roles. A comprehensive range of issues likely to impinge on the effective integration of women into the combat arms needs to be considered in any subsequent policy deliberations. These issues include operational requirements, habitability aspects, medical issues, occupational health and safety issues, posting requirements, social and demographic aspects, psychological issues, fraternisation and personal relationships, overseas military experiences and research, resource implications and community attitudes.
(6) Cadet instructors do not have to meet any specific physical fitness standards nor have there been any recent changes to medical standards.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 22 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to the diagram on page 6 of the Roads to Recovery Program annual report 2001-2002, what are the actual dollars and percentage of total funds used for (a) general maintenance, (b) reconstruction, rehabilitation, widening, (c) sealing, (d) bridges, (e) traffic improvement, (f) constructing a new road, (g) sheeting/resheeting, (h) resealing, (i) drainage, (j) bicycle paths, (k) footpaths and (l) other.

(2) Also further to the diagram, what is the actual percentage of funding directed to each Roads to Recovery key outcome, including (a) road safety, (b) improved access for heavy vehicles, (c) economic development, (d) traffic management, (e) equity, (f) access to remote communities, (g) access to international facilities, (h) asset management, (i) amenity, (j) improvements of school bus routes, (k) promotion of tourism and (l) improved recreational opportunities.
(3) Can a project example be provided for each outcome referred to in part (2).
(4) Was there a measure that included the number of jobs created as a result of the Roads to Recovery expenditure, if so what is it and what are the findings; if not, why not.

(5) Further to the comments on page 7 that 244 councils will be shielded from the funding changes announced in the May 2002 Budget rephasing of Roads to Recovery funds, (a) how many and which councils were not shielded from the funding changes announced in the May 2002 Budget, (b) by what sum was each such council affected by the funding changes and (c) how long will the rephasing delay the full receipt of each councils allocation.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The diagram on page 6 to which this question refers is derived from an analysis of all projects listed by councils for funding as at 30 June 2002.

(2) Councils must submit an annual report on their use of Roads to Recovery funding. As part of this report, councils must provide an estimated percentage of Roads to Recovery expenditure against each of the key outcomes listed. The diagram on page 6 to which this question refers relates to the information provided in the 2000/01 annual reports, at which time programme expenditure totalled $150 million.

entry.para: Estimated % of Roads to Recovery expenditure

quote.para: (3) As the analysis does not involve the listing of individual projects against each outcome, this information is not available.

(4) Neither the Roads to Recovery Act 2000, the Programme Conditions or Guidelines require Councils to give details of employment generated by the Programme because this is not a stated objective of the Programme. However, there is some evidence that the Programme has been a substantial employer, especially in rural and regional areas.
(5) (a) and (b)

* These councils have a life of programme allocation between $600,000 and $900,000. The rephrased allocation for these councils was set at $150,000 which partially shielded them from the rephasing. They were included in the list of shielded councils in the annual report.

** These councils received accelerated payments in 2001 as a result of which the amount remaining to be paid over the life of the programme is less than the rephased allocation for 2002/03 in each case.
A further 32 councils have received hardship funding to offset the rephasing since 30 June 2002 and are excluded from the list above.
(5) (c) All amounts gazetted to councils under the Roads to Recovery Act 2000 will be provided by 30 June 2005 in accordance with the Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on, 22 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that some 70% of bushfires are the result of arson.

(2) What can the Minister do to assist the States in the education of Australian citizens, particularly our youth, of the ramifications and cost to the Australian community of all types of fires caused by arson.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Education, Science and Training does not have any statistical information on bushfires arising from arson.

(2) As Commonwealth Minister for Education, I am aware that I need to do my part in assisting the teaching profession to guide young Australians to become good citizens, for example in respecting laws made to protect the community from arson.

Providing effective civics and citizenship education is a key to maintaining a strong and vital society in the future. From 1997 to 2000 this Government invested $18 million in civics and citizenship education through the Discovering Democracy programme, particularly to develop quality curriculum resources. A further $13.6 million is extending the programme to June 2004 so that teachers receive professional development to fully embed the programme in schools.

The report Citizenship and Democracy - Australian Students Knowledge and Beliefs - The IEA Civic Education Study of Fourteen Year Olds (Australian Council of Educational Research and University of Canberra) which was commissioned by my Department and published in 2001 indicated that while four out of five young Australians appreciate living in a vibrant, free, independent and democratic society, there are a number of young people who are alienated from society.

Education is as much about building character as equipping Australia's young people with skills. All Education Ministers agree to the National Goals for Schooling in the Twenty-First Century including Goal 1.3 about students accepting responsibility for their own actions.

I have commissioned a Values Education Study, which was supported by all State and Territory Ministers of Education at the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs meeting in July 2002.

Over 600 school applications have been received for grants in response to this study. Many of these schools are working with disengaged youth and are keen to have help in overcoming students' anti-social behaviour.
In early December, I announced the successful schools that will receive up to $7,000 to help them to develop and implement values education in their school.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 22 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that some 70% of bushfires are the result of arson.

(2) What can the Minister do to assist the States in the education of Australian citizens, particularly our youth, of the ramifications and cost to the Australian community of all types of fires caused by arson.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr Tuckey
talker.role: Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) While a significant proportion of bushfires or wildfires are suspected to be the result of arson, a consistent national approach to the collection and analysis of bushfire data has not been established. I understand that work is being undertaken by the fire authority members of the Australasian Fire Authority Council to establish the framework for the provision of information of this nature to the Productivity Commission.

(2) There is no doubt that arson is a significant cause of bushfires in all jurisdictions in Australia. In recognition of that, all fire agencies have in place some form of program aimed at reducing the incidence of arson, and most programs focus on juveniles.

Primary responsibility for firefighting and crime prevention rests with the States and Territories. In many respects, programs aimed at reducing the incidence of arson fall within the realm of crime prevention and are the responsibility of State and Territory Police Forces, emergency services or National Parks and Wildlife, depending on functional arrangements within the jurisdiction.

In terms of more general assistance, Emergency Management Australia, a Division of the Attorney General's Portfolio, provides funding assistance on behalf of the Commonwealth to improve community awareness of the risks posed by natural and technological hazards. School education, and warning systems and the community are themes under this funding programme. States seeking Commonwealth assistance for specific arson reduction programs can submit proposals to Emergency Management Australia and those proposals will be considered in competition with other disaster mitigation projects for available funding.

Notwithstanding the above and its serious implications, statistics arising from the Select Committee investigation into the 01/02 fires in NSW indicate very clearly that 750,000 hectares of NSW National Parks were destroyed by fire and only 2000 hectares of State Forests; this compared to the ratio of the total land areas managed by the two agencies, which was approximately 2 to 1 respectively. In my view, the failure of National Parks and Wildlife Services to practise recognised hazard reduction was a major cause of the magnitude and scope of the fires whatever the initial means of ignition. I condemn both acts of deliberate and or indiscriminate ignition of such fires but forestry management and adequate access routes can ensure that such fires do not do the damage recorded in recent years.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 October 2002:

question.para: (1) How many settlement deeds have been received by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in relation to the settlement offer issued by the Tax Commissioner for investors in mass-marketed tax-effective schemes, where investors were given until 21 June 2002 to take up the offer.
(2) How many ATO staff have been allocated to process settlement applications.
(3) What is the timetable set out by the ATO to process settlement applications.
(4) When will the ATO process payments arising from accepted settlement deeds.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Commissioner has advised me that approximately 51 400 deeds have been received by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in relation to the settlement offer announced on 14 February 2002.
(2) There are currently 148 members of staff allocated to process settlement applications. However this number fluctuates according to demand.
(3) The plan states that 90% of the deeds should be processed by 30 December 2002. This is dependent on taxpayers providing correct and full information.

(4) The ATO is working on a priority basis so that people who have previously paid their debt will have their deeds processed first. The exact timing depends on when the ATO receives all the necessary information.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 October 2002:

question.para: (1) How many permanent staff did Telstra hire in (a) 2000, (b) 2001 and (c) 2002.
(2) How many apprentices did Telstra indenture in (a) 2000, (b) 2001 and (c) 2002.
(3) What funds has Telstra allocated for repairs and replacement of new equipment being installed in remote areas when that equipment comes out of warranty.
(4) How many regional centres, staffed with experienced technical people, did Telstra have in September (a) 1999 and (b) 2002.
(5) What was the staffing level of technical people in the Kununurra region of Western Australia in September (a) 1999 and (b) 2002.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Based on information provided by Telstra.

In 1998, Telstra introduced the single Customer Field workforce structure. Multiskilling that followed allowed for traditional technical and lines field staff to become multi-functional, resulting in the whole field workforce being able to work on and maintain the access network.

Whilst Telstra has seen reductions in traditional field staff numbers as a result of contracting out installation/maintenance work, these external contractors employ their own staff to carry out this work.
Having regard to the above, the following information is provided.
(1) Telstra hired the following staff in:

(2) Telstra, in line with Australia-wide developments in industry training, now employs graduates from the various tertiary institutions around Australia rather than apprentices. Consequently, Telstra did not take on any apprentices during 2000 to 2002.
(3) Telstra does not keep data on expenditure related to warranty issues.

(4) (a) In September 1999, Telstra had a centralised structure, with seven regional centres serving specific geographic locations, ie Queensland, New South Wales North, New South Wales South, Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia/Northern Territory and Western Australia.

(b) In June 2000, Telstra, to better meet the needs of people in rural and remote areas for reliable, up to date communications services, formed Telstra Country Wide (TCW). As of September 2002, TCW was based in 28 regional centres.

(5) Telstra's network is increasingly digitised and some types of service work can now be undertaken remotely. Moreover, Telstra has invested $20b over the last five years to upgrade the network to a world class standard making it more robust. Telstra's strategic investment into the network means that fewer staff are required to maintain the network.
(a) In 1999 the Kununurra region of WA was serviced by 34 technical staff .
(b) In 2002, the Kununurra region was serviced by 31 technical staff.

Data is only available by state, Centrelink Customer Service Centre and Centrelink Area Region. talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

quote.para: Will he consider granting a fifteen year service medal to local government rangers similar to the fifteen year service medals granted to Police and Ambulance Officers and State Emergency Service and Rural Fire Service volunteers; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The National Medal is awarded for fifteen years diligent service to members of “service organisations” (police forces, the Australian Protective Service and those members of the following services who perform the primary function of the service: fire, ambulance, emergency and correctional services) and to members of certain voluntary search and rescue groups.

New organisations can be considered for access to the medal if they meet the strict criteria laid down in the regulations. In the case of new government organisations the criteria are “that the organisation is similar to a service organisation because the primary function of the organisation is to enforce the law in order to protect persons or property and some or all of the members of the organisation are exposed to the risk of death, injury or trauma in the course of performing that function.”

The Commonwealth is prepared to consider access to the National Medal for local government rangers. It is a matter for the state and territory governments to demonstrate that the medal criteria are met.

subdebateinfo.title: Family Law Court: Disputed Property Cases
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1076)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the present average time taken to settle a disputed property case in the Family Law Court.
(2) How does this compare with the average time taken to settle a disputed property case in the Family Law Court in (a) 1995, (b) 1996, (c) 1997, (d) 1998, (e) 1999, (f) 2000, (g) 2001 and (h) 2002.
(3) Are Family Law Court settlements being prolonged, inter alia, as a consequence of the property price boom, particularly in Sydney; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised by the Family Court of Australia that:

(1) Disputed property cases in the Family Court of Australia can settle at a number of stages between filing of an application and a defended hearing. All cases pass through a resolution phase before moving to the determination phase. Only approximately 6% of all applications filed are determined by a judge after a defended hearing. Selected studies have shown that approximately 80% of cases filed are settled/resolved within six months of filing. The Court implemented a new case management system (Casetrack) throughout 2002. When this system has been implemented for long enough to ensure accurate data collection, the Court anticipates being able to provide more detailed information about the time taken to settle property disputes. In the meantime, it is able to give figures which relate to the small percentage of cases that proceed to a trial.

The Court no longer measures averages, as the Portfolio Budget Statement outcomes are measured in percentiles. The 50th percentile for the 2001-2002 financial year for those cases that were listed for a final hearing is 13.5 months for property matters (from filing to settlement). This figure takes no account of the vast majority of cases which are not so listed.
(2) The Court's outcomes are measured in financial years. The following data is available as a comparison to the answer to Question 1. Again, this relates only to those matters listed for trial:

The Court adopted comprehensive electronic measurement of matters listed for final hearing in July 1998. Therefore, information for the periods prior to July 1998 is not provided because it would be either incomplete or misleading for the purpose of this question.
(3) The Court is not aware of any impact which changes in property prices might have on the time taken to settle family law matters.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the benefits for diabetic sufferers of the drug Glitazones.
(2) When will the Government include Glitazones on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Avandia (generic name, rosiglitazone), a drug sponsored by the pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline and Actos (generic name, pioglitazone), sponsored by Eli Lilly are two new oral medications for the treatment of Type 2 diabetes. They are substantially more expensive than other oral treatments for this condition listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Each of these drugs have been recommended for inclusion on the PBS by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), the Government's advisory body on PBS listings, but only for use in a limited group of patients whose diabetes is difficult to control with other oral medications.

There is considered to be a strong demand for both Avandia and Actos outside the patient group proposed by the PBAC and a real risk there will be major use on the PBS in the wider diabetic population. If this occurred, use of these drugs on the PBS would not be cost effective and there would be considerable Budgetary costs.

The Government has not agreed to list Avandia and Actos on the PBS to this point. However, my Department is continuing to work with GlaxoSmithKline and Eli Lilly to try to find a basis for subsidising these drugs that acceptably limits the Budgetary risks to the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What revenue is raised annually from the 15 per cent automotive tariff?
(2) What sum is derived from (a) imports of assembled vehicles and (b) imported components?

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) It is estimated that in 2001-02 tariff revenue raised on imports of automotive items rated at 15 per cent was $764 million.

There are nearly 400 recognised customs tariff classifications that include automotive products, with the tariff rates on these items ranging from 5 to 15 per cent. Around 150 of these items incur a tariff rate of 15 per cent.
The estimated tariff revenue is derived from data supplied by Australian Customs Service to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
(2) Of the $764 million, it is estimated that: (a) $496.5 million came from imports of assembled vehicles; and, (b) $267.5 million came from imports of automotive components.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Is it true that a computer programming or other administrative error caused the issuing of incorrect superannuation statements by the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme (PSS); if so, from what date were these statements wrong.
(2) How many people are affected by the error.
(3) Will this error result in all those affected having to do revised tax returns and having their tax re-assessed; if so, what is the range of additional tax that would be payable by these retirees.
(4) Is the Government considering waiving the additional tax payable; if not, who will pay any costs incurred by these retirees as a direct result of the error by the PSS.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) ComSuper implemented a new computer system for pensions in May 2002. In migrating pensioner data to the new system, ComSuper identified pre-existing errors in the Undeducted Purchase Price (UPP) and Rebatable Pension amounts held for some PSS pensioners. A decision was taken in June 2002 to review the UPP and rebatable pension amounts of all PSS pensioners, to correct any errors found and to advise affected pensioners of the changes.
The data was re-calculated from the date of exit for each PSS member. The revised UPP and Rebatable Pension amounts were provided back to 1994.

(2) Revision of UPP and Rebatable Pension amounts was necessary in 1,723 instances. This affected somewhat less than that number of PSS pensioners as some pensioners had errors in both the rebatable and UPP amounts quoted them.
1273 cases involved errors in the rebatable pension amount (549 overstated and 724 understated).
There was an additional 450 instances with errors in the UPP (184 overstated and 266 understated).

(3) All affected pensioners were contacted in July and provided with revised information between July and September 2002. Though it is ultimately a matter for the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) to determine, the pensioners were advised of the potential need to contact the ATO for reappraisal of relevant tax returns. ComSuper has supplied the revised data to the ATO. ComSuper is unable to comment on how the ATO will consider these cases.
The range of additional tax involving errors in the rebatable pension amounts is:
· 927 cases (73%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of less than $200.
· 306 cases (24%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of between $200 and $400.
· 40 (3%) cases are understood to involve a maximum annual tax variation of greater than $400.
The range of additional tax involving errors in the UPP amounts is:
· 366 cases (80%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of less than $200.
· 42 cases (10%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of between $200 and $400.
· 42 cases (10%) are understood to involve a maximum annual tax variation of greater than $400.
(4) This question should be referred to the Australian Taxation Office as it falls within their authority.
ComSuper will, on request, reimburse reasonable expenses that are incurred by PSS pensioners in submitting amended taxation returns.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department planning to relocate Centrelink's Records Management Unit from Cardiff, NSW.

(2) If so, (a) why, (b) to where, (c) how many jobs will be lost in the Hunter, (d) what is the cost of the relocation and (e) will Hunter-based clients not experience delays when seeking decision reviews or pursuing appeal rights as a consequence of the move.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) Area Hunter's current Offsite File Storage facility at Cardiff has reached maximum capacity. Several options were explored in order to identify the most appropriate solution for servicing the Area's records management requirements into the next decade. Options considered included:
1. Additional file storage racking installed to increase storage capacity of current facility.
2. Additional floor space leased adjacent to current facility (dependent on availability).
3. Relocation of files to Sydney Records Management Unit at Chullora.
Based on an evaluation over 10years of information/projections in relation to:
· Capacity - demand/supply.
· Cost - one off/on-going.

Relocation of the RMU to Chullora represented a significant saving to Centrelink of approximately $3 million over 10 years, as well as enabling future capacity. This option also aligned with Centrelink's strategy to maximise economies of scale in relation to Offsite File Storage by having a number of large facilities that service several Areas within each state.
(b) Sydney Records Management Unit, Chullora NSW.

(c) There are currently 6 ongoing positions located at the RMU. Options for re-deployment to other Centrelink positions within the Hunter region are being investigated. Temporary (non-ongoing) staff have been engaged on a needs basis.
(d) The anticipated cost of transferring Area Hunter files to Chullora is $150,000.

(e) The current records management unit at Cardiff have service-level agreements with each site in Area Hunter which prescribes request turnaround times. There are also courier contracts in place which contain agreed service standards to support the above agreements.

As a result of the relocation, service level agreements will be established between the Sydney RMU and Area Hunter sites to maintain current turnaround times. Courier service contracts will specify overnight delivery services from Chullora, as is the current arrangements from Cardiff.
Centrelink does not anticipate any reduction in the standard of service provision to Hunter-based clients.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Which OECD member Governments have not ratified Convention 182 regarding the Worst Forms Of Child Labour.
(2) What action, if any, is the Australian Government taking to ratify the Convention.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Australia
(2) The Government is carefully considering the necessary steps to ratify the Convention.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: DOTARS recognises the need for employees to establish an appropriate balance between work and family commitments.

To meet this goal the Department offers a range of flexible working conditions and leave provisions, the support of an Employee Assistance Program and the facilitation of home based work arrangements.

· Personal Circumstances leave enables employees to better balance the competing demands of work and personal life, by offering a category of leave that can be interpreted broadly to cater more effectively for the wide diversity of individual needs of employees.

· In addition to a number of long-term flexible work practices offered to employees such as part-time work, extended band-width and annual leave at half pay, the department has incorporated into it's 2002-2004 Certified Agreement a number of initiatives designed to complement existing provisions.
Some examples include:
The capacity for an employee to work more hours across fewer days,
Employee funded breaks (enabling an employee to plan a long absence and continue to receive a salary while on leave),
The capacity for two staff members to share the duties of one position (usually part-time), and
The capacity for staff to access Maternity leave at half pay.
· The Department has in place procedures to assist staff who have been absent from work for an extended period of time to better manage their return to the workplace.
· The DOTARS Home Based Work program enables employees to undertake duties from home on either a short- or long-term basis.

· A Carers room and Nursing Parents facility is provided for employees in the principal Canberra address. These facilities have been provided as an alternative to taking leave to care for a dependent in an emergency situation.
· An Employee Assistance Program provides a professional and confidential service to all DOTARS staff and their family regarding any work or non-work difficulties experienced.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so, what are those policies and or practices.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Australian Public Service employees of the Department of Defence are covered by the Defence Employees Certified Agreement (DECA 2002-2003). One of the core principles of the Agreement is `assisting employees to balance their work and private commitments'. This is expanded in Part E of the Agreement `Balancing Work and Life', a copy of Part E of the Agreement has been forwarded separately to your office. Below, is an overview of its provisions:

answer.para: · Flexible working arrangements such as flexible working hours, flex time, home based work, part time work, job sharing, time off in lieu of travel undertaken outside of the normal working day;

· Flexible leave arrangements - annual leave with an option to purchase an additional four weeks per year; Christmas stand down; personal leave for illness and caring purposes; long service leave; leave without pay; maternity leave and miscellaneous leave for bereavement, parental, special and study purposes, and one leave day per year which can be taken for unspecified purposes. With agreement, employees may work on public holidays and substitute an alternative day off for their own cultural or religious commitments;

· Nursing mothers' and family rooms for family responsibilities such as breast-feeding, short-term emergency dependant care. Family and nursing mothers' rooms may also be used for medical treatment, religious purposes and a quiet space for meditation or reading;
· Access to Defence provided child care - centre-based and family day care;
· Groups are encouraged to introduce other child care initiatives such as vacation/holiday programs to meet regional needs;
· Reimbursement of dependent care costs when Defence places additional work demands on an employee and no other option but paid care is available;
· A Health and Wellbeing Strategy which incorporates work/life balance and health and fitness initiatives, to assist staff to develop resilience in times of change and crises.
· Participation of employees (APS) in Australian Defence Force (ADF) representative sporting, cultural or community activities an on-duty basis where appropriate;
· A Defence-wide employee assistance program to provide access to professional counselling services for all employees and their dependants; and
· Access to Defence amenities and facilities on an appropriate basis with Australian Defence Force colleagues.

quote.para: Since the implementation of the DECA 2002-2003, the focus is on marketing the availability of these policies and the appropriate ways of accessing them. Employees and supervisors are targeted through up-to-date web-sites, an information hotline, guides to the DECA principles and policies, and the publication of the Defence Workplace Relations Newsletter, which provides information on the policies and their implementation.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Staffing
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1094)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The policies and practices that have been introduced into the department to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities are outlined in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) Certified Agreement, the Workplace Diversity Plan and a message from the Secretary to all departmental staff on 27 September 2002 concerning work and personal life balance.
The policies and practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities include:
Flexible Working Arrangements

The department offers its employees a range of flexible working arrangements to assist them in balancing work and personal responsibilities, including variable working hours, part-time work, job-sharing, home-based work and flextime.
Balancing Work and Personal Life

The department promotes workplace practices that assist staff to balance their professional and personal responsibilities. These include guidelines for managing meetings efficiently, strategies to manage information overload, time and workload and processes that encourage health and well-being.
Flexible Leave Arrangements

The department is committed to providing employees with streamlined leave arrangements which facilitate flexibility. Types of leave available to assist employees balancing work and family responsibilities include sick and personal leave, parental leave, maternity leave and purchased leave. The department also maintains a family leave pool for employees to access when they have carer and other family responsibilities.
Employee Assistance Program

The department provides its employees with access to confidential, professional counselling services to assist with work or personal issues. These services are also available to the family members of employees.
Carers' Room
The department maintains a Carers' Room intended for use by employees to cater for family or personal needs or emergency care situations.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: In July of this year, my Department implemented a new two-year certified agreement covering most Departmental employees. The agreement has a strong focus on work and life balance. Initiatives implemented under the agreement include:
- Home-based work options for either fixed or indefinite periods.
- Five days paid paternity leave and five days paid adoption leave.
- Up to 52 weeks unpaid parental leave.
- The ability for employees to extend the period of payment for maternity leave to a period of up to 24 weeks at half pay.
- Maintaining a carer's room and facilities.

- Part-time work arrangements are available to all employees. An employee is also entitled to work on a part-time basis during any period within 3 years from the date of birth of a child or placement of an adopted child.
- Sick and carer's leave which is not based on a leave credit system but which is managed on the basis of reasonable needs and trust.

- A variable 48/52 leave scheme which entitles employees to access additional paid leave by reducing annual salary. This is currently utilised by many employees who wish to take leave during school holidays.
- Christmas closedown providing employees with an additional two days leave over the Christmas period.
- Providing employees the option to observe a day of cultural or religious significance instead of a standard public holiday.
- Financial assistance for relocation expenses for a person who is relocating on engagement to and promotion to, or assignment with the Department.
- Reimbursement of whole or part of removal expenses for an employee who retires or for the dependants of an employee who dies.
- Extending the bandwidth of hours within which employees are able to work their normal hours to provide more flexibility to employees, particularly those with caring responsibilities.

In addition, the Department provides employees and their families access to an Employee Assistance Program and conducts regular seminars on balancing work and life through the Department's People Development Scheme.

Underlining these initiatives, the Department is committed to and places importance on developing a working environment where employees are able to balance their work and personal responsibilities in a flexible and safe workplace. The Department recognises that employees need to balance their working life commitments with other competing interests such as family and community responsibilities and lifestyle choices.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The Department of Finance and Administration (Finance) has an extensive program to cover work and home life balance. The principle objective of this program is:

para.inline: “To develop an environment where people can achieve high performance within a supportive, flexible and safe environment, whilst maintaining a healthy balance between work and home.”

answer.para: Work and home life balance is incorporated into both Finance's business planning and performance agreement frameworks.
A section of the Finance intranet site is dedicated to educating managers and employees on Finance's work and home life balance program.

Flexible working arrangements are provided for in the Finance Certified Agreement and in individual AWAs. They can also be arranged directly between employees and managers. Examples of flexibilities utilised include:
· Employees being able to elect to work part-time hours to enable them to study, care for children, or pursue other personal interests/responsibilities.
· Support for employees who need to work from home, for example, to care for sick family member, which may include provision of computer equipment and online access to Finance's IT network.
Finance has established an Early Childhood Centre, which opened on 22 July 2002. Employees are able to salary sacrifice their payments to the Centre.

It also provides a Mother's Room and has also entered an agreement with the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia to provide a Maternity Information Leave Kit (MILK) to employees commencing maternity leave.
A Department-sponsored gym is located in Finance's main building.
Health services, including on-site annual flu vaccinations and first aid facilities are provided to all employees. In 2002, 339 flu vaccinations were given to departmental employees.
An employee assistance program is supported by a confidential, independent and free counselling service for employees and their families.
A dry cleaning collection and delivery service has also been established for employees.

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Work Practices
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1098)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies or practices.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) Certified Agreement 2000-2003 outlines the Department's commitment to providing employees with the flexibility to balance both personal and professional commitments and to plan and manage individual workloads to maximise productivity and balance work and personal commitments.

The AFFA Certified Agreement 2000-2003 has provisions for employees to undertake home based work, part-time work or job sharing arrangements. It also provides employees with the flexibility to use Personal Leave provisions for personal illness or unanticipated short-term personal circumstances that may arise that requires absence from the workplace.

Maternity Leave and Parental Leave provisions are also outlined in the AFFA Certified Agreement 2000-2003. Employees are entitled to 12 weeks paid maternity leave, with this entitlement also able to be paid over a 24 week period at half pay.
Individual work plans and learning agreements allow for discussion between the employee and their supervisor about balancing work and family responsibilities.

Other initiatives including the implementation of the Performance through People program in AFFA; access to an Employee Assistance counselling service for AFFA staff and their families; encouragement of Vacation Care and Holiday Programs for children of staff; the provision of a carer's room in the Edmund Barton Building; and free seminars on planning for life after work.

subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services: Work Practices
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1099)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: “Building stronger families” is a key policy objective for FaCS, so developing family-friendly work practices provides FaCS as an employer with an opportunity to practice what it preaches. Considerable effort has been invested in raising awareness and understanding of work/life policies among staff by using the intranet, promotional activities, statements of support from senior executives, a lunchtime seminar program and an annual Health Expo.

Including work/life balance initiatives in the FaCS Certified Agreement and Diversity Plan helps secure organisational and individual commitment to integrating work/life balance into the way the Department does business. A Work-Life Diversity Team is supported in the workplace by a network of contact officers in each Branch and State/Territory Office.

Issues have been identified through annual employee surveys and consultations and negotiations for the Department's Certified Agreement. Measuring and improving performance are also key goals and this involves data analysis and benchmarking work/life balance initiatives.
The Department has implemented a range of innovative policies and practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities, including:
· flexible working arrangements such as access to single days annual leave, part-time, career breaks, time off in lieu, hours negotiated by employees and teleworking;
· unlimited personal leave (with supervisor approval and appropriate documentation);
· paid maternity leave (12 weeks), including access to part-time employment upon return;
· paid adoption leave (12 weeks, non-gender specific);
· Parental leave (52 weeks, non-gender specific);
· a network of family support rooms;
· family friendly meeting times for Senior Executives (9.30am start);
· a dedicated Work-Life Diversity team and a network of Work-Life Diversity contact officers;
· support for employees' participation in corporate volunteering and a community work placement scheme;
· a free Work-Life Balance Information and Referral Service;
· a breast pump loan scheme for breastfeeding mothers;
· flexible working arrangements such as school term only work are available;
· Learning at Lunch seminars are held to promote issues such as healthy eating, parenting, dealing with teenagers, stress management and laughter therapy;
· annual organisation-wide family fun day;
· extra family care costs if an employee is required to be away from home outside of normal hours and a school holiday family care subsidy;
· a strategy to promote flexible and balanced working arrangements for Senior Officers;
· an older employees retention strategy and an Employee Mobility Program;
· an annual Health Expo for staff, a Health Promotion Program, Health Assessment Program, ergonomic workstation assessments and free flu vaccinations.

In September 2002, the Department was recognised for its achievements in providing a family-friendly work environment by jointly winning a National Work and Family Award in the Large Business category run by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and practices.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Yes. The Department of Health and Ageing has implemented an extensive Health and Life Strategy to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities. The strategy is a commitment made in the Certified Agreement 2000 and is an overarching term used to describe what the Department does to support and help its staff to balance the high demands of their work with their private life. It also seeks to assist staff to improve their health and well being thus to remain productive and continue to add value to the organisation.

Some of the existing initiatives include the Organisational Health Strategy, services offered by the Employee Assistance Program, flexibility in hours of attendance, working from home, part-time work, family care assistance and school holiday family care subsidy and the personal leave package. The new Certified Agreement expands the existing initiatives by offering: health and fitness screenings, funding for teams in fitness/health challenges, support for health/fitness week, a seminar series on a range of health and well being issues, support for volunteers and investigating information and support options for older workers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) values the diversity of its employees and has employed a number of initiatives and conditions of service to enable employees with family responsibilities to better balance these responsibilities with work. The Department's flexible workplace arrangements are integrated with all aspects of DVA's people management policies and practices to enable employees to balance work and caring commitments which are of course subject to operational requirements. Options available to employees provided under the Department of Veterans' Affairs Enterprise Agreement 2002-2003, Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service Enterprise Agreement 2002-2003 and the Office of Australian War Graves (Field Employees) Agreement 2002-2003 include:
· flexible working hours;
· 18 days personal leave per year, an unlimited amount of which can be used for caring purposes;
· 12 weeks paid maternity leave is available;
· purchased leave of up to an additional 4 weeks is available to employees. This is particularly valuable to employees with school-age children;

· a Christmas shutdown, commencing this year, will be available for the first time to enable employees to have a substantial break with their families. Arrangements are being made to ensure that essential services to the Veteran Community are maintained throughout this period;
· part-time and job sharing opportunities are available to employees;
· an on-site family room is provided, so that employees can maintain caring responsibilities in emergency situations;

· home based work is available to employees if the requirements of their position can accommodate this arrangement. Home based work is not strictly available for caring purposes but can assist the employee to balance these commitments; and
· an Employee Assistance Program is also available to employees and their families should they need the support of professional, independent counselling services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the hardship provisions of Lifetime Health Cover.
(2) Did applications for consideration under the hardship provisions expire on 30 June 2002.
(3) Did these provisions have a financial impact on the Government's budgetary position.
(4) Will the Minister consider allowing the reintroduction of the hardship provisions; if not, why not.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(4) The hardship provisions will not be reintroduced as they were transitional provisions to assist a smooth introduction of the Lifetime Health Cover policy. The Government continues to monitor the effectiveness of Lifetime Health Cover and recently announced changes for new migrants and veterans. Other changes may be considered in the future if appropriate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Further to longline fishing and the threat abatement process for boats leaving Mooloolaba, Qld, what action is being taken to protect the Fleshy Footed Shearwaters.
(2) Will the line below which bird mitigation is required be shifted from 30 degrees latitude to 20 degrees latitude.
(3) Do any fishing boats fish below the current 30 degrees latitude without bird mitigation.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Longline vessels leaving Mooloolaba and fishing south of 300S must use the following seabird by-catch mitigation measures:
· bird scaring or tori lines which must be used at all times;
· longlines to be set only at night, when seabirds are generally less active; and
· no discharge of offal to occur when lines are set or hauled.

No mandatory measures, other than the discharge of offal regulation, are in place for vessels operating north of 300S where potential bird by-catch is considered to be low. However, bird-scaring lines must be carried and used where necessary.

The only exemption to setting lines at night is for scientific purposes. The Australian Fisheries Management Authority can issue scientific permits to operators where a technique of setting and hauling longlines which does not make the baits and hooks available to seabirds can be demonstrated, or is under investigation.

(2) Commonwealth agencies are working to collect further data on bird by-catch north of 300S. An observer program, with high priority given to the area between 250S and 300S is intended to commence in early 2003, and will provide enhanced information. The program will take a further six months at which time the results will be reviewed by experts and government agencies.
(3) Refer to (1).

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Further to his replies to questions No. 678 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8680), No. 861 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8697) and No. 862 (Hansard, 24 September 2002, page 6877) and in light of the Director of Public Prosecution's (DPP's) recent decision to review the state of health of former Senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston in relation to his capacity to stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts, will Dr Colston be exhaustively and thoroughly medically examined on this occasion by appropriately qualified and competent expert medical specialists who have never previously examined Dr Colston; if not, why not.
(2) Further to his reply to part (3) of question No. 678, why did the DPP not request an up-to-date medical report on the state of health of Dr Colston between 9 February 2001 and July 2002.

(3) Since 1 July 2002, has Dr Colston been thoroughly and exhaustively examined by appropriately qualified and competent expert medical specialists in relation to his capacity to stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if so, (a) what are the qualifications, competencies, disciplines and experience of the specialists who have examined Dr Colston; (b) did the DPP provide to the most recent examining doctors copies of the medical reports dated 14 May 1999 and 19 May 1999 by the previous independent expert eminent medical specialists who examined Dr Colston and opined in May 1999 that Dr Colston only had months to live; (c) did the DPP provide to the most recent examining doctors a copy of the taxpayer-funded motor vehicle and aircraft travel records of Dr Colston since 1 July 1999 reflected in the answer to question No. 862 and (d) on what dates did these medical examinations take place.
(4) Is he able to say whether Dr Colston is terminally ill; if so, what is Dr Colston's life expectancy.

(5) What assistance can he give to Dr Colston to provide Dr Colston with the opportunity to clear his name and stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Dr Colston is being examined by an expert medical specialist who has never previously examined Dr Colston.
(2) In the light of the medical advice received.

(3) Dr Colston has been physically examined by an appropriately qualified and competent expert medical specialist. (a) Professor of Medicine. (b) Yes. (c) The DPP has informed the doctor of Dr Colston's travel. (d) 10 October 2002.
(4) The medical review of this matter is not completed.
(5) The prosecution of offences against the laws of the Commonwealth is the responsibility of the DPP.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 13 November 2002:

question.para: (1) How many requests for ministerial intervention and exercise of his statutory discretions under sections (a) 48B, (b) 137N, (c) 345, (d) 351, (e) 391, (f) 417 and (g) 454 of the Migration Act has he received in each year from 1996 to 2002, inclusive.

(2) Is he aware of any other statutory power under the Migration Act or any other Act that gives him discretionary power to substitute a decision of his Department or the Migration Review Tribunal or Refugee Review Tribunal with a more favourable decision of his; if so, what are those provisions.

(3) Is he able to provide details of the number of successful interventions granted each from 1996 to 2002 inclusive against each of the statutory powers referred to in part (1) and to compare those figures against the number in which he declined to exercise his power.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) to (3) Questions 1(a) and 3: Section 48B Note: Section 48B does not provide the Minister with a discretionary power to substitute a more favourable decision. Rather, the Minister may exercise his power under s48B to allow a person subject to the s48A application bar to make a further application for a protection visa.

entry.para: (a) Total number of requests for intervention

answer.para: ^ The statistics under each year represent annual activity figures only.
* Information not available.
** Note: decisions taken in relation to the exercise of the power are not necessarily taken in the same financial year as the requests are received.
Questions 1(b) and 3: Section 137N (Ministerial intervention power to revoke the automatic cancellation of a student's visa; commenced June 2001)

entry.para: (a) Total number of requests for intervention

answer.para: Questions 1(c) and 3: Section 345 (repealed in 1998); and
Questions 1(d) and 3: Section 351 (equivalent clauses) (Ministerial intervention power to substitute a more favourable decision for an MRT decision)

entry.para: (a) Total number of requests for intervention

answer.para: * Information not available.
** Note: decisions taken in relation to the exercise of the power are not necessarily taken in the same financial year as the requests are received.
Questions 1 (e) and 3: Section 391 (Ministerial intervention power to substitute a more favourable decision for an AAT decision on a case which has been referred to the AAT by the MRT)

entry.para: (a) Total number of requests for intervention

answer.para: Questions 1(f) and 3: Section 417 (Ministerial intervention power to substitute a more favourable decision for an RRT decision)

entry.para: (a) Total number of requests for intervention

answer.para: ^ The statistics under each year represent annual activity figures only.
* Information not available.
** Note: decisions taken in relation to the exercise of the power are not necessarily taken in the same financial year as the requests are received.
Questions 1(g) and 3: Section 454 (Ministerial intervention power to substitute a more favourable decision for an AAT decision on a case which has been referred to the AAT by the RRT)

entry.para: (a) Total number of requests for intervention

answer.para: (2) There is one other statutory power in the Migration Act or any other Act that gives the Minister discretionary power to substitute a decision of the Department, or the merits review tribunals which have jurisdiction to review Departmental decisions, with a more favourable decision. This is section 501J, which commenced on 1 October 2001. This section gives the Minister discretionary power to substitute a more favourable decision for an AAT protection visa decision. There have been three requests for Ministerial intervention under section 501J and all were received this financial year (2002/2003). The Minister did not exercise his power to intervene in two cases, the third request is currently being processed.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 November 2002:

question.para: (1) When was the Governor-General appointed.
(2) Since being appointed, how many days and nights has the Governor-General been overseas.
(3) What was the itinerary for each overseas trip and who accompanied the Governor-General on each trip.

(4) What was the cost of each trip for the Governor-General and those who accompanied him, including airfares, travel allowances, ground transport expenses and other expenses incurred by the taxpayer.
(5) How many days and nights has the Governor-General spent in (a) Melbourne and (b) Brisbane and for each visit, what was the cost and who accompanied him.
(6) How many days and nights has the Governor-General stayed at Admiralty House, Sydney.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I am advised by the Official Secretary to the Governor-General that the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) 29th June 2001
(2) 32 days and 30 nights
New Zealand 21 February to 24 February 2002
Canberra - Wellington - Canberra (Special Purpose Aircraft flights)
Mr Martin Bonsey (Official Secretary)
Ms Maria Cicutto (Aide to Mrs Hollingworth)
Mr Ross Perriman (Valet)
Federal Agents, Mark Jager and Greg Mowle
Europe 13 April to 30 April 2002
Sydney - Singapore - London - Istanbul - Ankara - Gallipoli - Istanbul - Paris - The Somme - Amsterdam - Oudeschild Harbour (The Netherlands) - Amsterdam - Singapore - Sydney (commercial flights)
Mr Martin Bonsey (Official Secretary)
Ms Maria Cicutto (Aide to Mrs Hollingworth)
Ms Claire Tedeschi (Speech Writer)
Mr Ross Perriman (Valet)
Dr Graeme Killer (Physician)
Federal Agent Mark Jager, Federal Agent Greg Mowle
Group Captain Timothy Owen, ADC (from London for Turkey)
Egypt and Indonesia 13 October to 23 October 2002
Sydney - Singapore - Dubai - Cairo - Alexandria - El Alamein - Alexandria - Cairo - Dubai - Singapore - Bali - Darwin - Canberra (commercial except Special Purpose Aircraft for return from Bali)
Mr Kevin Davidson (Senior Adviser)
Ms Maria Cicutto (Aide to Mrs Hollingworth)
Ms Claire Tedeschi (Speech Writer)
Mr Roger King (Valet)
Dr Graeme Killer (Physician)
Federal Agent Suzanne St Jorre
LtCol Simon Gould, ADC (from UK)
(5) (a) Melbourne: 50 days, 24 nights at hotels and 18 nights at Government House.
(b) Brisbane: 24 days, 14 nights at hotels and 7 nights in July 2001 at previous residence.

All staff accompanying the Governor-General to Melbourne and Brisbane travelled by Special Purpose Aircraft and details are included in the Special Purpose Aircraft Flight Manifests regularly tabled in the House.
I am not prepared to authorise the work required to detail the cost of each visit by the Governor-General to Melbourne and Brisbane.
